text: CAMERA FLIES OVER the "Welcome to Couer d'Couers" sign at the field's edge to FIND a bright, care-free boy of about (YOUNG NED) racing through the flowers sending petals fly as he chases his dog DIGBY, an adorable yellow lab as bri and care-free as Young Ned. Our OMNISCIENT NARRATOR (imag Patrick Stewart reading a bedtime story) begins:
At this very moment in the town of  Couer d'Couers, Young Ned was 9 years,  27 weeks, 6 days, and 3 minutes old.

Young Ned is only a few feet behind his dog, 3 sets of le speeding through the brush. He reaches out trying to make contact, but Digby is just out of touch. Closer... closer The brush gives way to a clearing. Closer... closer, stil
His dog Digby was 3 years, 2 weeks,  6 days, 5 hours and 9 minutes old.
WHAM. Out of nowhere, Digby is HIT BY A PASSING SEMI-TRUC A BLUR OF BIG RIG obscures the impact. Ned stops, horrifi
And not a minute older.

TIME SLOWS TO A CRAWL. FUR SAILS THROUGH THE AIR, as if D was taking flight by his own propulsion. ALL SOUND DROPS except for the RAPID, RHYTHMIC POUNDING of Ned's HEART an the EXPANSION AND CONTRACTION of his LUNGS. He approaches the unmoving body of his dead dog Digby.
This was the moment Young Ned realized  he wasn't like the other children.  Nor was he like anyone else for that  matter.
Ned kneels down beside Digby and as he reaches out to str the dog's matted fur... CAMERA JUMP CUTS TO:
The ridges of his fingertip look like circular troughs. A Ned touches his dog we see a small STATIC POP OF ELECTRIC between his finger and Digby's fur.
TIME RESUMES TO NORMAL as Digby inexplicably scrambles to his feet with a happy dog-smile on his face and runs off  into the field of daisies.
Young Ned could touch dead things  and bring them back to life.
Young Ned watches slack-jawed and furrow-browed as Digby  disappears over the horizon. He stares at his finger, not sure exactly what just happened.
It lands on a cupboard door and darts to and fro until SM A FLY SWATTER ends its life in one abrupt movement. We ar
The dead fly lands on the counter top. Young Ned's MOTHER sets the fly swatter down and returns to lovingly prepari a pie, pressing dough into the pie plate.
It was a gift given to him, but not  by anyone in particular. There was  no box, no instructions, no  manufacturer's warranty. It just  was.
Young Ned peers over the edge of the counter, reaching in and touching the dead fly. There's a small ELECTRIC POP t the fly flies up and out the open window.
The terms of use weren't immediately  clear nor were they of immediate  concern.
CAMERA FOLLOWS THE FLY and Young Ned's gaze to:
A girl named CHUCK, pig-tails et al, plays in the back ya
Young Ned was in love.
She's making a small village out of mounds of dirt and  cardboard boxes with Play-Doh people and toy cars as her  FATHER waters the lawn in the background.
Her name was Chuck. At this very  moment, she was 8 years, 42 weeks, 3  hours and 2 minutes old.
She squeezes a little people head out of the Play-Doh Fun Factory and places it on the body she's already construct
Young Ned did not think of her as  being born or hatched or conceived  in any way. Chuck came ready made  from the Play-Doh Fun Factory of  Life.
She makes the final few touches on her village and it COM TO LIFE THROUGH THE MAGIC OF IMAGINATION.

Large as life, TOY CARS drive through tiny streets, and T PEOPLE mill about on tiny sidewalks. BOOM. BOOM. BOOM. BOOM. The ground SHAKES. The TOY PEOPLE react to the strangeness... then a GIANT REPTILIAN LEG ST into a cardboard building, crushing it. CAMERA REVEALS A GIANT PIG-TAILED GODZILLA stomping throu the village, sparing no one as PLAY-DOH PEOPLE SCRAMBLE. And just when we think a lone TOM CRUISE-ESQUE PLAY-DOH P has escaped... SQUISH. A GIANT RODAN-ESQUE WINGED DINOSAU looking as much like Ned as the Godzilla looks like Chuck (wearing the same clothes, etc.) stomps him good.
Chuck and Ned are stomping through the remains of her sma village, having an absolute ball and getting very dirty.
His Mother is sweeping the dirt off of him with a broom.
Freshly broomed, Young Ned stares out the window as filth Chuck is getting hosed off in the backyard by her Father.
He was under Chuck's spell... until  a blood vessel in his mother's brain  burst, killing her instantly.

head_text.subj: MOMENT THEN ABRUPTLY DROPPING OUT OF FRAME.

text: Young Ned turns away from the window to find his Mother d on the linoleum floor next to the stove.
Young Ned reaches into FRAME and touches his Mother's che just below the eye. A BOLT OF STATIC ELECTRICITY. Her  constricted pupil dilates and Ned's Mother blinks. DING. The timer goes off.
He slowly backs away as his Mother stares at him. A CLOCK appears in the corner of the OUR SCREEN and begins counti down from ONE MINUTE. 59 seconds... 58... 57...
Young Ned's random gift that was  came with a caveat or two...
Did the timer go off?
Young Ned nods as his Mother gets to her feet, brushes of her apron and pulls on a pair of OVEN MITTS.
I must've slipped. Clumsy. Hmmm.
Ned sits at the kitchen table, unable to look away as his Mother pulls a pie out of the oven. 37 seconds... 36... Ned's Mother places the pie in the kitchen window to cool
She kicks over the last standing building and runs inside her Father continues to water the lawn in the background. The COUNTDOWN continues... 23... 22... 21...
Ned watches as his Mother readies a second pie to go into the oven. 11... 10... 9... 8...
It was a gift that not only gave...  it took.
Ned's Mother twists the timer around, puts a new pie in t oven and as she closes the oven door. The CLOCK HAND has  traveled almost full circle: 4... 3... 2...
Young Ned discovered he could only  bring the dead back to life for one  minute without consequence. Any longer  and someone else had to die.

INCLUDE THE KITCHEN WINDOW, through which we can SEE Chuc Father drop dead. Young Ned and his Mother don't immediat see this because their backs are to the window. Ned's Mother cuts a piece of pie, puts it on a plate, and sets it down in front of Young Ned. He takes a bite. Heav
It was the most delicious pie ever  baked because it was the pie that  was not meant to be.
His Mother's GASP draws his attention to the window, wher they can see Chuck's Father dead in the yard.
Ned stares out the window at an AMBULANCE slowly pulling  away from Chuck's house without its lights on, horrified.
Young Ned realized somehow in the  grand universal scheme of things, he  had traded his mother's life for  Chuck's father's.
Come on, big daddy, into bed.
And he was horrified.
Ned's Mother pulls up the blankets so Ned can slide into  bed. She draws the blanket up to his chest. (NOTE: Never  touching him directly.)
But there was one more thing about  touching dead things that Young Ned  didn't know. And he learned it in  the most unfortunate way.
She moves to kiss Ned on his forehead.
As they're about to make contact with his forehead, we se STATIC POP OF ELECTRICITY.
Ned's Mother drops dead right then and there.
First touch, life. Second touch,  dead again forever.
Ned kneels next to his dead mother, poking her cheek, wai for her to open her eyes again. She doesn't.
Young Ned sits on the porch, dressed all in black. He wat as Chuck's 30-something Grey Garden-esque aunts (VIVIAN a LILY) drag large steamer trunks into Chuck's house.
Chuck was orphaned when her father  died and fostered by her aunts Vivian  and Lily. A renowned synchronized  swimming duo, they shared matching  personality disorders and a love for  fine cheese.
Young Ned watches as his FATHER fills a steamer trunk wit all the belongings from his room, his Rodan costume,
For all intents, Young Ned was  orphaned, too. After a brief mourning  period, his father panicked at raising  a child alone. In the wake of that  panic, Ned was hustled off to boarding  school.
The JEWISH and CHRISTIAN GRAVEYARDS are two halves of the same cemetary. The Synagogue and Church on either end of
hillside graveyard. Two funerals are taking place, one on each side of the graveyard.
At their respective parent's  funerals...
The peak of the cemetary hill. Young Ned and the Neighbor Girl ENTER FRAME from their respective side, silhouetted the sun. She takes his hand and kisses him on the lips.
...dizzy with grief, curiosity and  hormones, Young Ned and a girl named  Chuck had their first and only kiss.

Young Ned watches the Neighbor Girl head back down the hi After a moment, Young Ned's dog Digby returns and bounds  right up to Ned. He reaches out to pet Digby and the dog  pulls away. Despite this, Digby wags his tail and smiles, keeping a safe distance. As Young Ned leads Digby down th other side of cemetary hill, CAMERA BEGINS TO PULL BACK..
The effect of his Mother's death on  Ned's psyche was twofold. He avoided  social attachments, fearing what  he'd do if someone else he loved  died.  Secondly, he became obsessed  with pies.
The setting sun shining bright and round MORPHS INTO A GO BROWN PIE on a cloud-print tablecloth. We are:
It's 19 years, 34 weeks, 1 day and  59 minutes later...
We're on a cooling window, the shelves lined with the  cloudprint tablecloth. On a pillow on the floor, is DIGBY
Young Ned has become "The Pie-Maker,"  owner and pastry chef of "The Pie  Hole."
CAMERA FINDS a PAIR OF HANDS rolling and kneading dough.
The expression "pie in the sky"  entered popular culture in 1911,  referring to a dessert so sweet it  can only be found in heaven. But...

A charming Parisian (in tone)/American (in style) googiee bakery. The front of the business is rounded and given th facade of a giant pie wedged into the ground floors of an ADJACENT APARTMENT BUILDING, complete with a pie-crust ro A sign reads: The Pie Hole.
...if you crave something before you  die I recommend where the Pie Maker  makes his pies.
CAMERA PUSHES IN ON the back of the Pie Maker as he works lining the pie pan with dough, not yet showing his face.
The peaches never brown. Berries  ripe as the instant they were plucked.  If they weren't so delicious and  eaten so quickly, folks might notice  the pies stayed fresh an unusually  long time.
Dead, dying or bruised fruit is lovingly picked from a bo and placed into the empty pie crust. Bruises fade and dea fruit spontaneously engorges with juice, ripe and tasty.
That's because the Pie Maker  personally touches the contents of  every one.
A piece of NOW FRESH fruit spills out of the pie crust.
The dead fruit in his hands becomes  ripe with ever-lasting flavor -- as  long as he only touches it once.
The Pie-Maker's hand snatches it before it hits the floor and the fruit spontaneously shrivels and darkens.
For this reason, the Pie-Maker is a  vegetarian.
Simultaneously handsome and awkward, about 30 years of ag Ned's lips are whistling but we don't hear a sound.
He bakes alone, whistling quietly to  himself, rarely pursing his lips  tight enough to produce a sound.
Digby cocks his head, listening to what no one else can h

Rich and textured, like the inside of a pie. Tufted booth and a rounded counter bar (with spinning stools) that cur parallel to the pie facade exterior. Right out of the 40' The place is dappled with customers and a single WAITRESS CAMERA FINDS OLIVE, a 20-something waitress waiting on re customer EMERSON, a late 30's/early 40's African-American man in a seersucker suit.

Every day I come in, I pick a pie  and concentrate all my love on that  pie.  If I love it, then someone  else will love it. And you know what?  By the end of the day I've sold more  of those pies than any other pie in  the bakery.
Yeah? What pie do you love today?
Rhubarb.
I'll stick with three plum. Ala mode.
Emerson Cod, soon to be enjoying a  slice of three plum pie ala mode,  was the sole keeper of the Pie Maker's  secret.
EMERSON chases a RUNNING MAN across a rooftop.
And how he came to be the sole keeper  of the Pie Maker's secret...

The Running Man jumps to make it to the next building and misses, plunging 10 stories to his death. Emerson looks o the ledge to see the Running Man HIT a trash bin with a B CRUNCHING WHAM that most definitely killed the man.  But BOUNCES into a SLIGHTLY YOUNGER NED who happened to be  emptying the trash at the time. CAMERA JUMPS TO AN EXTREME-EXTREME-EXTREME CLOSE UP of th impact and we SEE the POP OF STATIC ELECTRICITY. CAMERA POPS WIDE as the Dead Running Man OPENS HIS EYES a takes off again. Slightly Younger Ned gives chase. Emerson watches as Slightly Younger Ned tackles the Runni Man and he goes limp.
After the runaway corpse, Emerson  Cod, a Private Investigator, proposed  a partnership with the Pie Maker.
CAMERA PUSHES IN ON Emerson staring, slack-jawed.
Murders are much easier to solve  when you can ask the victim who killed  them.
Ned watches Emerson through the porthole window in the ki door. Emerson looks up from his pie. Their eyes connect.
Since the bakery was on the verge of  financial ruin, the Pie Maker agreed  so he could keep his Pie Hole open.

It's after hours and the bakery is closed. Blinds are dra over the windows and the lights are dim. As CAMERA FINDS and Emerson sitting at a booth speaking in hushed tones. Ned, forever the handsome, articulate recluse, fidgets a  bit, uncomfortable in his own skin. Digby sits nearby  listening to them MID-CONVERSATION:

I asked you not to use the word  "zombie."  It's disrespectful.  Stumbling around, squawking for  brains. That's not how they do. And  "undead?" Nobody wants to be un- anything. Why begin a statement with  a negative? It's like saying "I don't  disagree." Just say you agree.
Are you comfortable with "living  dead?"
Ned shakes his head for a long beat.

You're either living or you're dead.   When you're living, you're alive.  When you're dead, that's what you  are. And when you're dead and then  you're not, you're alive again. Can't  we say "alive again?" Doesn't that  sound nice?
Sounds like you're a narcoleptic.
I suffer from sudden and  uncontrollable attacks of deep sleep?
What's the other one?
Necrophiliac.
Words that sound alike get mixed up  in my head. Used to think masturbation  meant chewing your food. Now are you  interested in this opportunity or  not? (off his hesitation) A dog is involved.
(glances at Digby) What kinda dog?
Gonna be a dead dog. A dead dog named  Cantaloupe. Putting her down.  Allegedly killed her owner.
When you say allegedly --
Cantaloupe was framed. Someone put  part of the victim in her mouth.
Huh.
Docile as a kitten, says the family.
Emerson holds up a picture of the dog, a chow.
Despite it being a chow -- the breed  most likely to turn on its owner.
That's racial profiling. Looky here,  if the dog's innocent, it's murder.  If it's murder, then there's a reward.
The facts were these: one Leonard  Gaswint, 39 years, 42 weeks, 5 days,  3 hours and 26 minutes old, was found  mauled to death in a parking garage.
A chow named Cantaloupe cleans himself next to a parked c which partially obscures Leonard Gaswint's corpse.
His dog Cantaloupe was the soul  witness and only suspect in the  murder.
There's a business photo of Leonard Gaswint with text tha reads: "REWARD $20,000."
Convinced of her innocence, the  Gaswint family offered a significant  reward to find the real killer.
Cantaloupe sits alone in her cell, awaiting execution.
Ned and Emerson stand outside the morgue with the CORONER who is filling out a series of forms on a clip board. TWO COUNTY SHERIFFS stand nearby, looking official.
You the dog expert?
Uh-huh.
Already had a dog expert.
I'm the, uh... other one.
Emerson and Ned approach a sheet-covered body on a slab. Ned peeks under the sheet and Emerson takes a step back.
How's he look?
He looks fine, but my threshold is  pretty high so you have to take what  I say with a grain of salt.
Emerson takes a peek under the sheet himself.
It's not a grain of salt. It's one  of those blocks they give cows to  lick.  The man's tore up.
He can't help the way he is.
It doesn't make it any less traumatic.
For who?
Me. And I'm sure him. But mainly me.   I'm fine when they don't move. It's  when they move that I have a problem.
Would it help if I turned off the  light?
Yes.
Ned turns off a metal floor lamp next to the drawer, cast a shadow over the body and obscuring it. Emerson pulls ba the sheet and reacts to the OFF-CAMERA corpse, mortified.
I'm gonna wait outside.

Ned watches as Emerson quickly disappears out the door. A Ned's about to touch dead Leonard Gaswint's hand... CAMER JUMPS TO AN EXTREME-EXTREME-EXTREME CLOSE UP and we see t FAMILIAR POP OF ELECTRICITY. Ned sets the alarm on his wa A CLOCK appears in the corner of the SCREEN and begins  counting down from ONE MINUTE. 59 seconds... 58... 57... Leonard Gaswint sits upright into the light revealing he' been MAULED. He couldn't be nicer.
Hello.
Hi. Sorry to disturb you, Mr. Gaswint.   Or Leonard. Do you prefer --
Leo.
Leo. Your, um, current condition...
Ned indicates the missing part of Gaswint's face. The clo continues to count down: 43... 42... 41...
Do I have something right here?
No. There's nothing right there.
Damn dog.
Cantaloupe?
No, no. Cantaloupe's docile as a  kitten.  It was that rottweiller. My  secretary sicked her dog on me. She's  been upset since last year's Christmas  party. You know, it's a funny story...
Before Gaswint can start, Ned touches him and life slips  from his body instantly. He stops his watch at 27 seconds
The Coroner and the Two Sheriff Deputies stand outside, a before, alone with Emerson. Ned steps out of the morgue.
Was it the chow?
The Secretary. With a rottweiler.
Cantaloupe bounds out of her kennel and down the aisle, h fellow kenneled dogs barking M.O.S. in support.
SECRETARY and the ROTTWEILLER are escorted out of her  apartment building, surrounded by MEDIA and POLICE.  CAME PULLS BACK TO REVEAL the image is on TV. We are --
CAMERA CONTINUES PULLING BACK TO REVEAL Olive sitting in over-stuffed lounge chair, Digby squeezed in next to her, his head on her lap. They're watching the evening news.
An anonymous tip led to solving the  murder of a Michigan entrepreneur  believed to have been fatally mauled  by a family pet. The truth, however...
KNOCK-KNOCK. Someone's at the door.
Olive opens the door to find Ned standing on her stoop.   Digby pokes his head out from around the lounge chair. Th NEWSCASTER continues to prattle on in the background.
How was your convention?
She draws close to him, flirtatious and almost slightly  desperate for him to seduce her. He doesn't engage.
Conventional. How was Digby?
Neurotic. He's a very needy dog.  Do  you pet him? Maybe if you pet him  once in a while he wouldn't be so  neurotic.
Ned steps inside and around Olive.
I pet him. I'm allergic so I can't  actually touch him. But I pet him.
With a stick? How do you pet him?
A stick is involved, but it's more  like a handle to a... petting device.
The dog needs to be touched. We all  need to be touched.
You touch him. Other people touch  him.
He's your dog. Do you touch anything?
Of course I... I touch lots of things.
With affection?
She reaches out and touches his shoulder, holding her han there an uncomfortable beat. Ned innocently averts his ey
When was the last time someone touched  you with affection?
I get touched.
She holds his gaze for another uncomfortable moment. He c his throat, she finally pulls back her hand.
Can I get Digby's leash? (to Digby) You don't mind that I don't touch  you, do you?
Digby smiles and wags his tail, happy to see Ned.
And then came the event that changed  everything.
Ned's attention is drawn away from Digby and to the telev news broadcast. A NEWSCASTER reports:
In other news, the body of a young  woman allegedly murdered aboard a  cruise ship was recovered from the  sea. Her identity is being held  pending notification of...
Ned watches on the television as an image of a LIMP, LIFE WOMAN is hauled out of the water by a system of pulleys o the deck of the cruise ship.
The Pie-Maker listened intently to  the news, unaware that he stopped  breathing.  He was haunted by the  nameless woman who met her end on  the high seas.
Olive approaches with Digby's leash in hand.
Here's your leash.
But he didn't know why.
OFF Ned, totally rapt, ignoring Olive...
Ned has one eye on the pies he's making and the other on small television set in the corner of his kitchen.
Her name still withheld, very little  is known of the victim, who was  reportedly traveling alone when ...
Ned gives Digby a scratch with the petting device.
...murdered aboard a passenger ship  returning from a tropical cruise.
Ned looks up from the television to see Emerson through t porthole window in the kitchen door -- he's seated at a b in the restaurant. Their eyes connect.
It's after hours and the bakery is closed. Blinds are dra over the windows and the lights are dim.
Been watching the news?
Doesn't seem like much is going on  in the world besides a dead girl on  a boat.
A lot's going on with that dead girl.
That so?
Mmm-hmm. 100,000 dollars of that's  so.  Interested in a conversation?
I could be persuaded.
You better be persuaded quick cause  dead girl's about to go in the ground.
They just pulled her out of the water.
Jewish. Christians leave 'em laying  around. Jews gotta get 'em buried.
Where we going?
Coeur d'Coeurs. Ever been there?
I grew up there. Sort of. (lost, then:) So this dead Jewish girl from Coeur  d'Coeurs. She have a name?
Charlotte Charles.
POW. He might as well have punched Ned in the stomach.

-- Young Chuck stomping through the dirt city in her yard -- Young Chuck and Young Ned at Halloween. She's Godzilla he's Rodan, they hold their candy bags out for goodies. -- Young Chuck and Young Ned kissing in the graveyard.
Chuck?
Ned and Emerson sit opposite each other next to a window.
You know this girl?
I know of her.
Know of her in the biblical sense?
Haven't thought of her since I was  10.
Think of her a lot when you were 10?
Don't remember anything when I was  10.
The Pie-Maker remembers everything.
CAMERA IS ANGLED UP at the undulating surface of the wate SPWOOSH. A BODY breaks the surface in a cloud of bubbles.
The facts were these... Charlotte  Charles, 28 years, 24 weeks, 3 days,  11 hours, and 51 minutes old, was  found floating in the ocean moments  after her body was discarded there.
The silhouette of dead Charlotte Charles floats in the su
Discarded by whom seemed to be a  question only Charlotte Charles could  answer.
A simple, pine casket. The lid is set in place over  Charlotte's beautiful, lifeless body. We don't see her fa
Jewish law prescribes burial in a  plain white shroud to demonstrate  equality for all. No bling. For this  reason...
The FUNERAL DIRECTOR, a chain-smoking obese man, stands  outside the Home as MOURNERS file inside.
...the nondenominational Funeral  Director preferred non-Jewish  services.
-- The Funeral Director opens the coffin lid and pulls th NECKLACE off of a DEAD WOMAN'S neck. -- ...pulls the WATCH off a DEAD MAN'S wrist. -- ...pulls the SIZEABLE RING off a DEAD WOMAN'S finger.

The Funeral Director continues to watch MOURNERS file in. CAMERA FINDS Ned and Emerson approaching in the throng of mourners. Emerson begrudgingly slips the Funeral Director some cash, he quickly pockets it and opens the door.
The simple, pine casket in the middle of the room surroun by much fancier coffins. The afternoon sun shines through window -- a light on the pine casket. Emerson and Ned ENT
Um, I just wanna... I wanna... Can't  I do this one alone? On account of,  you know, the whole historical  context?
Got something personal you wanna  say?
No. Okay, perhaps. I have nothing to  gain but a small amount of closure.
Wha'cha got so open it needs closing?
Just wanna say I'm sorry for  something.  One of those stupid things  kids do... that they don't know  they're doin'.
You ask who killed her first.
Okay.
You only got one minute.
I know.
60 seconds.
I know.

Emerson walks out eyeing Ned, who closes the door behind  him. Alone in the room, Ned braces his back on the door a takes a deep breath. Gulp. He slowly approaches the caske Ned runs his hand over the pine frame then lifts the lid, bathing the body of Charlotte Charles, aka CHUCK, in sunl
Only Prince Charming could know how  the Pie-Maker felt upon looking at  her.
Even in death she's beautiful, a woman yet very much the  little girl he once knew.
Great thought was taken as to where  to touch her. The hand too impersonal,  lips too forward, the cheek... the  cheek.

Ned's finger closes in on Chuck's alabaster cheek and CAM JUMPS TO AN EXTREME-EXTREME-EXTREME CLOSE UP of his slow  caress. A CRACKLE OF ELECTRICITY between finger and cheek A CLOCK appears in the corner of the SCREEN and begins  counting down from ONE MINUTE. 59... Chuck opens her beautiful eyes and blinks. Ned can only s back at her. The moment is as electric as his touch.
He smiles at her, expecting a warm smile in return but  instead... WHAM. She grabs him by the jacket and SLAMS HI HEAD between the coffin and its lid. WHAM-WHAM-WHAM.
OW.
Chuck scrambles out of her coffin as Ned stumbles back in daze. She grabs a chair and raises it to hit him again.
Chuck! Wait.
Who are you?
Do you remember the little boy who  lived next door to you when your dad  died?
Yeah...
We used to destroy small villages  together?
Chuck stares at him a moment... confused... then...
Ned? Hey. How's it going?
She finally puts the chair down. 46... 45... 44...
Good. You look great. Um, do you  know what's happening right now?
I had the strangest dream I was being  strangled to death with a plastic  sack.
It wasn't a dream. You were...  strangled to death with a plastic  sack. That's probably an odd thing  to hear but I wasn't quite sure how  to sugar-coat it.
It takes a moment. She glances at her burial shroud, her  coffin and finally the viewing room filled with caskets.
Oh. Oh. And I'm...? Neat. How...?
You only have a minute. Less. About  38 seconds.
Huh. What can I do in 38 seconds?
You can tell me who killed you so,  um, you know, justice can be served.

That is so sweet. I just wanna put  you in my pocket. But I don't know  who killed me. I went to go get ice.  I was filling my bucket and I dropped  my room key in the ice maker and  just as I was thinking that was  dumb...

CHUCK stands at the ice machine perplexed with a bucket o ice under her arm. FWIP - a bag is thrown violently over head. She sucks air and it shrink-wraps to her face. The ice tumbles to the deck in the FOREGROUND as Chuck is murdered in the BACKGROUND.
...then you touched my cheek.
BEEP-BEEP-BEEP: Ned's watch alarm goes off. 15 seconds le
Is my time up?
I'm sorry.
And Chuck was just starting to get used to being alive ag It's weird and sad, but all she can think to say is:
Thanks for calling me Chuck. Nobody's  called me Chuck since... you.
Emerson RAP-RAP-RAPS on the door.
I heard you beeping.
Just a second.
Chuck back in her coffin, Ned holding the lid. 11... 10.. He stumbles on his words, trying to speak but overwhelmed
Before you...
Yeah?
I wanted to say I'm...
Staring at her, Ned can't bring himself to tell her he  inadvertently killed her father. So instead he says:
I used to... when I lived next door  to you... I had a cru... I was in...  You were my first kiss.
(smiles, touched) You were my first kiss, too. Or did  you think I'd been around?
I didn't want to assume.
Wanna be my last kiss? First and  last?  Or is that weird?
It's not weird. It's symmetrical.
5... 4... He looks at her and slowly moves in for the kis She closes her eyes. Their lips are about to connect when
The Funeral Director scoots into the stall, pulling down pants, sitting on the toilet and striking up a cigarette.
Ned and Chuck, their lips hang in the air, centimeters ap
His lips went as far as they would  go.  He couldn't will them to go any  further.
Chuck opens her eyes. 2... 1... Minute's up.
A beat, then THUNK -- we HEAR The Funeral Director's life head hit the stall door. Then the smoking cigarette drops
Ned slowly pulls away from Chuck, who lies there blinking He let her live and someone else died, the weight of it a is clearly on Ned's face when he looks back at Chuck.
If you don't wanna kiss me, you  don't... It was just a... I thought  it might...
No. I want to, I do... I... What if  you didn't have to... be dead?
Well, that would be preferable.
RAP-RAP-RAP, Emerson pounds on the door.
Nobody can know. I have to think  about how to get you outta here. Can  you lay really still until I get  back?
Uh, sure --
Before she can finish, he's closing the coffin lid.
Ned emerges from the viewing room, quickly shutting the d behind him. He's nervous and a little sweaty.
She doesn't know. Didn't know.

Chuck emerges from the second story and climbs down the r trellis. She turns back to see:
Ned's looking out the window at Chuck. The wail of approa sirens can be heard in the distance.
Chuck runs across the yard and stops at the dead Plastic  Sack Killer and kicks him.
A rush of warmth washed over the Pie  Maker, he would later describe this  feeling as delight. The girl he  rescued from death had returned the  favor.
Ned turns from the window to find Lily holding the stainl steel briefcase as Emerson and Vivian come up the stairs.
The lid pops open to REVEAL there are no monkeys, but ins it's filled with HONEYCOMB. A single bee flies out.
And she gave a little sweetness to  the ones she left behind.
Ned, Emerson, Vivian and Lily watch the lone bee fly out window and into the night.
POLICE and NEWS VANS parked in the street outside the fen POLICE OFFICERS, REPORTERS and CAMERA-MEN storm through t gait and stop short at an unusual sight.
He's laying sprawled out surrounded by broken glass.
They step out onto the porch, surveying the REPORTERS and gathering CROWD OF LOOKILOOS
And saw that the Darling Mermaid  Darlings had another go at the teat  of stardom.
She's wearing scarf and long-coat, watching from the gath CROWD OF LOOKILOOS.
Hey. Aren't those the world-renowned  Darling Mermaid Darlings?
The Reporters glance at Chuck, then back at Lily and Vivi then swarm to the Darling Mermaid Darlings in a CACOPHONO MURMUR OF QUESTIONS and GASPS. Chuck smiles, pleased with herself...
Newscaster #1, seen earlier, reports breaking news:
Former "Darling Mermaid Darlings"  Vivian and Lily Charles defeated a  deadly home invader who may have  some connection to the murder of  their niece, "Lonely Tourist"  Charlotte Charles.
CAMERA PULLS BACK TO REVEAL we are --
CAMERA CONTINUES PULLING BACK TO REVEAL Olive again sitti in her over-stuffed lounge chair, Digby squeezed in next her. They're watching the evening news.
When asked about a "Darling Mermaid  Darlings" reunion the sisters  mentioned a benefit performance to  support "Honey for the Homeless" was  in the works.
Olive raises the television remote and we...
CAMERA FINDS Ned and Chuck seated at a booth enjoying pie
You know, this whole thing is sort  of like reincarnation but more  immediate.
Sort of.
Do you believe in reincarnation? If  I wouldn't have come back this way,  would I have come back some other  way?
I don't wanna believe in  reincarnation.
The planet's falling apart. Right  now it's the children's problem, but  if we reincarnate it's our problem.
Never thought of it that way. (considers) Was this an act of kindness? Me.   Here.  Were you trying to do something  good for no other reason than to  help me?
(shakes his head) I was being selfish. I'd love to  tell myself I was being unselfish  but I know deep down in my primal  sweet spot I was being unselfish for  selfish reasons.
Did you want a corpse bride?
No. I just thought the world would  be a better place if you were still  in it.
The most romantic things she's ever heard.
Anything else I should know?
The Pie Maker wanted to tell Chuck  about that fateful afternoon when he  brought his mother back and  inadvertently killed her father, but  instead he said...
You know everything there is to know.
He lied.
She slides one of the Monkeys across the table.
I figure since they cost me my life  I should get to keep at least one.  And since I wouldn't be alive if it  weren't for you, you should have the  other one.
It's like those heart pendants that  BFF's wear. Except with monkeys.
Thanks for bringing me back to life.
The word "life" hangs there. Chuck stares at Ned a moment The attraction is palpable, but is it love or fascination Not even Chuck could tell you. Ned's affection is clearer
Thanks for returning the favor.
Chuck takes her Monkey and presses its face against Ned's Monkey. Ned smiles returning the kiss with his Monkey. He feels the weight of the plaster statue.
These are kinda heavy.
Then: SMASH. Chuck smashes her Monkey against Ned's. The  plaster shatters revealing SOLID GOLD MONKEYS underneath.
Is that...?
Uh-huh.
Neat.
The flowers in the yard are blooming and there's a fresh  coat of paint being applied to the house. Lily and Vivian emerge and walk down the path to the gate, stepping out.
With a renewed interest in the world  on the other side of their fence,  Vivian and Lily retreated from their  retreat...
A large metal water tank with port hole windows in the si Vivian and Lily in robes and wearing bathing caps climb t stairs to the platform above the water.
...and took the plunge.
The VERY AMPLE CROWD APPLAUDS as Vivian and Lily DIVE!

head_text.subj: CAMERA PUSHES INTO THE PORTHOLE WINDOW

text: SPLOOSH-SPLOOSH. Vivian and Lily dive in and into each ot The porthole the window in a kitchen door. The door swing open to REVEAL we are:
CAMERA PUSHES PAST Emerson to find Ned and Chuck standing either side of the door to the WALK-IN FREEZER.
And the Pie-Maker and Chuck took a  plunge of their own...

CAMERA PUSHES BETWEEN Ned and Chuck to REVEAL they're sta over a FROZEN CORPSE. A clean-cut white professorial type his late 40's wearing a suit. His name is MARTIN MILTENBE and he's been stabbed several times.
The facts were these: one Martin  Miltenberger, Principal of the Beales  School for Boys was found stabbed to  death in the school's walk-in freezer.

As Ned's about to touch dead Martin Miltenberger... CAMER JUMPS TO AN EXTREME-EXTREME-EXTREME CLOSE UP and we see t FAMILIAR POP OF ELECTRICITY. Ned sets the alarm on his wa A CLOCK appears in the corner of the SCREEN and begins  counting down from ONE MINUTE. 59 seconds... 58... 57... Martin Miltenberger sits up and takes in his stabbed stat
But before Principal Miltenberger  could get into the specifics of his  demise, Chuck thought it would be  nice to ask...
Do you have any last words or thoughts  or requests?
Ned reacts, glancing at Chuck and loving her for asking.
It was something the Pie Maker never  thought or cared enough to ask until  Chuck back into his life.
You better ask who killed him first.
As Martin Miltenberger prattles on, Ned stares at Chuck, heart swelling. He reaches behind him and holds his hands behind his back.
As he stared at her, he reached around  and held his hand behind his back,  pretending he was holding hers.
Chuck winks at Ned and reaches behind her back.
And at that very moment she was  pretending to be holding his.
OFF Chuck and Ned holding their hands behind their backs.
